verses.text: After this, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
verses.comment: Job begins his lament, expressing deep sorrow by cursing his own birthday. This is a turning point where his suffering leads him to profound despair, foreshadowing the need for redemption.

verses.text: And Job spoke, saying:
verses.comment: Job now delivers his first extended speech in poetic form, highlighting his deep pain.

verses.text: "Let the day perish on which I was born, and the night that said, 'A man is conceived.'"
verses.comment: Job's language here is a cry for annihilation, longing for his own nonexistence, which contrasts with God's gift of life (Gen. 1:27).

verses.text: "Let that day be darkness; let not God above seek it, nor light shine upon it."
verses.comment: Job wishes his birth day erased from God's care, emphasizing his estrangement, reflecting humanity's need for reconciliation.

verses.text: "Let gloom and deep shadow claim it. Let clouds dwell upon it; let blackness of the day terrify it."
verses.comment: Job's imagery of darkness recalls Genesis 1:2, before God's light, and points to the hope for restoration through divine light.

verses.text: "That night—let thick darkness seize it! Let it not rejoice among the days of the year; let it not enter into the number of the months."
verses.comment: Job's plea is that his conception be totally erased from history, a poetic way to express ultimate despair.

verses.text: "Behold, let that night be barren; let no joyful shout enter it."
verses.comment: Desiring barrenness counters the biblical motif of fruitfulness as a blessing (Gen. 1:28).

verses.text: "Let those curse it who curse the day, who are ready to rouse up Leviathan."
verses.comment: "Leviathan" is an ancient chaos monster. In later biblical theology, Christ's victory over chaos and death is foreshadowed here (Isa. 27:1).

verses.text: "Let the stars of its dawn be dark; let it hope for light, but have none, nor see the eyelids of the morning,"
verses.comment: Desiring the removal of dawn echoes longing for an undoing of creation—pointing to the brokenness of the world apart from God’s saving plan.

verses.text: "because it did not shut the doors of my mother's womb, nor hide trouble from my eyes."
verses.comment: Job laments that he was allowed to be born into suffering.

verses.text: "Why did I not die at birth, come out from the womb and expire?"
verses.comment: A cry found elsewhere in scripture (Jer. 20:17–18); Job wishes he never saw life’s suffering.

verses.text: "Why did the knees receive me? Or why the breasts, that I should nurse?"
verses.comment: He questions the nurturing care that allowed him to survive, reflecting the tension between God’s providence and the mystery of suffering.

verses.text: "For then I would have lain down and been quiet; I would have slept; then I would have been at rest,
verses.comment: Rest and quiet here prefigure the Christian hope for rest beyond suffering (see Matt. 11:28).

verses.text: with kings and counselors of the earth, who rebuilt ruins for themselves,
verses.comment: Death as the great equalizer—rich and poor, powerful and weak lie in the grave together.

verses.text: or with princes who had gold, who filled their houses with silver.
verses.comment: The vanity of earthly riches is a theme repeated by Jesus (Luke 12:20–21).

verses.text: Or why was I not like a hidden stillborn child, like infants who never saw the light?
verses.comment: Job’s words echo the mystery of suffering and unanswered prayers, highlighting faith’s challenge.

verses.text: There, the wicked cease from troubling, and there the weary are at rest.
verses.comment: Death is described as a place of rest, a theme that points to the hope for eternal peace promised by Christ.

verses.text: There, the prisoners are at ease together; they do not hear the voice of the taskmaster.
verses.comment: Even the oppressed find release—an early biblical reflection on liberation for the suffering.

verses.text: The small and the great are there, and the slave is free from his master.
verses.comment: Equality in death prefigures the leveling of all before God’s judgment.

verses.text: "Why is light given to him who is in misery, and life to the bitter in soul,
verses.comment: Job’s rhetorical question touches on the divine mystery of human suffering.

verses.text: who long for death, but it does not come, and search for it more than for hidden treasures,
verses.comment: Despair is painted as an unfulfilled longing, yet Job continues to address God, hinting at a hope beyond despair.

verses.text: who rejoice exceedingly and are glad when they find the grave?
verses.comment: This verse vividly expresses the depth of Job’s anguish.

verses.text: Why is light given to a man whose way is hidden, whom God has hedged in?
verses.comment: The ‘hedge’ recalls Satan’s complaint that God protected Job (Job 1:10); now Job feels trapped. The image also hints at the need for spiritual guidance, which the New Testament fulfills.

verses.text: For my sighing comes instead of my bread, and my groanings pour out like water.
verses.comment: Job’s daily life is consumed by sorrow, like the sufferings Christ bore for humanity (Isa. 53:3–4).

verses.text: For the thing that I fear comes upon me, and what I dread befalls me.
verses.comment: Job’s greatest fears are realized; suffering as a means of spiritual testing recurs through the Bible, including in Peter’s trials (Luke 22:31–32).

verses.text: I am not at ease, nor am I quiet; I have no rest, but trouble comes."
verses.comment: This closing verse highlights Job's complete suffering and longing for peace—a longing ultimately fulfilled in the promise of Christ (“Come to me, all who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.” – Matt. 11:28).
